editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

In like manner he might have ≈øpared the reflexion that follows, he tel s me, he ≈øhall beg leave to follow his own method, and ju≈øtifie what he hath ≈øaid in the ≈øame order he hath aid it in; And then adds, his (his An≈øwerers) altering of which, has more of art than hone≈øty in it. Now if I had mi≈ørepre≈øented his Arguments, or perverted the ≈øen≈øe of them, or drawn from them any odious or uncharitable inferences, and with great hone≈øty in≈øinuated that he did not believe a Providence or had inclinations to Rome, Vindic. P. 48. 58. there might have been ≈øome colour for this reflexion. But if he hath notoriou≈øly done all the≈øe him≈øelf, as will plainly appear in the following di≈øcour≈øe, then his own reflexion fa≈øtens upon him, and he had better have let it alone, for his own ≈øake at lea≈øt, tho it had been civil enough for his An≈øwerer. But ≈øome men are very free of their challenges: But when they are an≈øwer'd, they are up in the boughs, and out of all bounds; the Drs. Hypothe≈øis was an≈øwer'd, and there is the plain Di≈øhone≈øty of the bu≈øine≈øs.

But as for his Method and Order, 'tis all one to me, he may take which he likes be≈øt to ju≈øtifie his Doctrines and Argum ‚Ä¢ nts, provided he will but ju≈øtifie them, but that he will not do, and as yet he hath not done; as will appear upon examining what he offers in his vindication.

The Dr. begins wi h a Proof from the Ob≈øervator, P. 2. an admirable Hi≈øtorian to fetch an in≈øtance from,T ‚Ä¢ tle of an U≈øurper Preface. if he plea≈øe in his next he may quote Mercurius Politicus or the London Diurnal, but this pretended Letter of King James
hath already been ≈øo well examin'd by a lea ‚Ä¢ ned Author that I have no occa≈øion to concern my ≈øelf any further with it. But if it were admitted to be true, and not ≈øuppo≈øitions: There is a great deal of difference between the judgment of King James, as it is expre≈ø≈øed in that Letter, and the Doctors; King James expre≈ø≈øeth it with words of abatement and caution, you have ≈øtumbled upon the thre≈øhold of that opinion, which makes God the Author of ≈øin, in ≈øaying upon the matter, that even Tyranny is Gods Authority; and again you ≈øay upon the matter. But the Doctor ≈øays it is as ≈øure as can be, and hopes he may be allow'd to believe his own ≈øen≈øes. As if King James might not have eyes and ≈øen≈øes as well as the Doctor: But what King James could not, did not charge directly upon the Convocation, the Doctor plainly declares to be the ≈øen≈øe of it, and hath made it the foundation, both of his freedom of thinking, and of writing a Book. Now ≈øuppo≈øe King James did conceive the expre≈ø≈øions of the Convocation had ≈øuch a tendency,Ca≈øe of Alleg. Preface. and that upon the matter they might mean ≈øo, (which is the utmo≈øt can be collected from the words of the Ob≈øervators Letter) is it impo≈ø≈øible, he ≈øhould afterwards be otherwi≈øe informed? And if not, I wonder how the Convocation went on, and proceeded to pa≈øs the Book in the upper hou≈øe of Convocation, and pa≈øs the other Books in the lower hou≈øe. And likewi≈øe afterwards to pa≈øs the Province of York. This could never have been done, except King James had been ≈øatisfied, that the words of the Convocation had no ≈øuch tendency as he ≈øeem'd to apprehend. For the Letter contains a direct prohibition to proceed, I ≈øhall give you orders about it by Mr. Sollicitor, and until then medate no more in it. But of this enough and too much, except we had ≈øome better account of the Authority of it.
And therefore let us come ( ‚Ä¢ s the Dr. ≈øays) to try the ≈øen≈øe of the Convocation, from the Convocation it ≈øelf.

The place is this ch. 28. pag 57, The Conv. having given account of the various revolution of Governments brought about by the Providence of God, who for the ≈øins of a Natio ‚Ä¢ or Country altereth their Governments and Governours, transferreth, ≈øetteth up and be≈øtoweth Kingdoms, as ≈øeemeth be≈øt to his heavenly Wi≈ødom. Add the≈øe words, and when having attained their ungodly de≈øires (whether ambitious Kings by bringing any Country into their ≈øubjection, or di≈øloyal Subjects by their rebellious Ri≈øing again≈øt their natural Sovereigns) they have e≈øtabli≈øh'd any of the ≈øaid degenerate forms of Government among≈øt their People, the Authority either ≈øo unju≈øtly gotten or wrung by force, from the true and lawful Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor, being always God's Authority (and therefore receiving no impeachment by the wickedne≈øs of tho≈øe that have it) is ever (when any ≈øuch alterations are throughly ≈øetled) to be reverenc'd and obey'd, and the People of all ≈øorts (as well of the Clergy, as of the Laity) are to be ≈øubject unto it, not only for wrath but al≈øo for Con≈øcience ≈øake.

He tells us,Ca≈øe of Alleg. p. 5. he ob≈øerved in the fir≈øt place from the words of the Convocation, That tho≈øe Princes who have no legal right to their Thrones, may yet have God's Authority, which (≈øays he) I proved, becau≈øe the Convocation ≈øpeaks of illegal and u≈øurped Powers, and yet affirms, that the Authority exerci≈øed by them is Gods Authority.

To this (≈øaith the Doctor) the Author an≈øwers, The Doctor will not, Po≈øt≈øcript p. 3. but the Convocation di≈øtingui≈øhes between the means of acquiring the power, and the power it ≈øelf, the means of acquiring
power, may be very unju≈øt and illegal, and yet the power afterwards may be very legal. But the Doctor re≈øolves they mu≈øt be all one, and becau≈øe the Convocation ≈øpeaks of the ambition of encroaching Kings, and the Rebellion of Subjects, as a means whereby Governments have been alter'd, therefore by a Government being throughly ≈øetled they mu≈øt mean u≈øurped powers, as if it were impo≈ø≈øible for ≈øuch beginnings afterwards to acquire a Right, and to terminate in a legal Title; and till that is, the Government is as unju≈øt as the Rebellion and encroachment. The≈øe I own to be my words, and further that the Doctor concludes rightly from them, when he ≈øays, that according to this Author, a Government which is illegally and wickedly begun, when it is legally ≈øetled has God's Authority, and this is all that the Convocation meant by it.

To this the Doctor replyes, As for what he ≈øays, that I will not di≈øtingui≈øh between the means of acquiring Power, and the Power it ≈øelf; I do not indeed di≈øtingui≈øh as he does, but I di≈øtingui≈øh as the Convocation does, that the means are wicked, but the Power and Authority is Gods, which is all the di≈øtinction the Convocation makes. Very well, and which I pray are the≈øe means that are wicked that the Convocation ≈øpeaks of? I know of none but the wicked means of acquiring the power, as by Rebellion, and ambitious encroachments; and what is the Power and Authority that is God's? The Convocation mentions no other, but a Government throughly ≈øetled, and if the Convocation di≈øtingui≈øhes between the≈øe (as it plainly does) then the Convocation di≈øtingui≈øhes as I do, whatever the Doctor di≈øtingui≈øhes; and by rea≈øon of that di≈øtinction, it cannot be concluded from the Convocation, that becau≈øe they ≈øpeak of the Ambition of encroaching Kings and the Rebellion of Subjects, as a means whereby Governments have been alter'd; therefore by a G ‚Ä¢ vernment being throughly ≈øetled, they mu≈øt needs mean u≈øurped Powers. And this I take to be the ground of the Do ‚Ä¢ tors a≈ø≈øertion, and he hath not yet contradicted it. He tells us (as above) that he ob≈øerv'd from the words of the Convocation: That tho≈øe Princes, who have no legal right to their Thrones, may yet have God's Authority: Which (≈øaith he) I proved, becau≈øe the Convocation ≈øpeaks of illegal, and u≈øurped Powers. But that is the Que≈øtion, which he begs and takes for granted, which yet is the main thing to be proved, and he did not before, nor hath yet offered to prove it. The Convocation ≈øpeaks indeed of, and condemns the wicked means of acquiring Power; and the Doctor ≈øeems from thence to conclude, that by a Government throughly ≈øetled, they mean u≈øurped Powers. He ≈øays here,Vindic. p. 4. when the Convocation ≈øpeaks of the ≈øettlement of illegal Powers, which began by Ambition and Rebellion; where he manife≈øtly confounds what the Convocation di≈øtingui≈øhes, and becau≈øe they ≈øay they began by Ambition and Rebellion, therefore the ≈øettlement they ≈øpeak of mu≈øt needs be the ≈øettlement of illegal Powers; whereas the Convocation ≈øpeaks not one word of the ≈øettlement of illegal Powers; they ≈øpeak indeed of the ≈øettlement of Powers which began by wicked means: But the≈øe are two different things, and the Convocation plainly di≈øtingui≈øhes them. When God has done this once, ≈øhall he never be at liberty to di≈øpo≈øe it otherwi≈øe, and will not the Dr. allow the Providence of God to change and alter, whatever rea≈ø ‚Ä¢ ns the Divine Wi≈ødom ≈øees for it; but what God has once done, he i ‚Ä¢ re≈ø ‚Ä¢ lv'd to abide by, whatever h ‚Ä¢ t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ks fit to do afterwards which is to oppo≈øe God's Authority, and to ≈øhackle and „Äà‚óä„Äâ providence, that it ≈øhall not after its u≈øual methods in the Government of the Wo ‚Ä¢ ld; which are his Arguments but the very page before, and if they prove any thing at all, they are equally valid again≈øt ≈øuch a Re≈øerve as again≈øt any other Legal Right; and if the D ‚Ä¢ . will an≈øwer them fairly, he will ≈øave any man the trouble of an≈øwering his Book. The Dr. adds, But the very nature of the thing proves, that ≈øuch di≈øputes which are too big for a Legal deci≈øion, or any Humane Courts, for the deci≈øion of which God has erected no univer≈øal Tribunal on Earth; he has re≈øerved to his own judgment, ≈øuch as the Correction of Sovereign Princes, and the transferring Kingdoms and Empires. And here the final determination of providence in ≈øetling Princes on their Thrones, draws the Allegiance and Submi≈ø≈øion of the Subjects after it, and in ≈øuch Ca≈øes God does not confine him≈øelf to determine on the ≈øide of Humane Right, but acts with a Sovereign Authority, and gives the Kingdoms of the World to whom he plea≈øe, as he can be≈øt ≈øerve the wi≈øe, and many times un≈øearchable de≈øigns of his providence by it. To this I an≈øwer, and becau≈øe he hath the ≈øame in other places, I ≈øhall do it di≈øtinctly.

1. The Rights of Princes may and ought to be determined by Law, as well as tho≈øe of Subjects. I have already in≈øtanced in the differences between the Hou≈øes of York and Lanca≈øter, where the Law hath decided the controver≈øie, and the Ca≈øe hath been the ≈øame in other Kingdoms; but I wonder whoever in≈øi≈øted on a Providential Title, or thought it a ≈øufficient competition for a Legal Ti ‚Ä¢ le: There is never a Prince nor private Man in Chri≈øtendom, nor the Dr. him≈øelf, that would change his Legal Title for a Providen ial one, which is a pre ‚Ä¢ ty plain Ca≈øe, that however ≈øome People may talk of it, no body believes it. But becau≈øe there are no Judges and Juries appointed, and the Rights of Princes are not to be tryed in We≈øtmin≈øter Hall, nor in other Courts of
Judicature; therefore Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Providence mu≈øt determine it: But this is manife≈øtly fal≈øe, for the Law is as proper a Judge of the Rights of Princes, as of any other; their Per≈øons are not under the Law, but their Titles are, and the Laws declare who is, and who is not King; as much as they do who is, or who is not any inferior Proprietor. And as to what the Dr. ≈øays of a Tribunal, I ≈øuppo≈øe he means to inforce this upon the Subject, (for the matter is declared by the Law, and there needs no Tribunal for that, no more than there needs a vi≈øible Judge of controver≈øies, in matters of Religion, 'tis a duty under the direction of the Law, and every Per≈øon concerned is bound to take notice of it.) But as for the other, if the Law may take its cour≈øe, there are Tribunals enough: But indeed when the Prince is di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, there is no Tribunal to force this, and to puni≈øh the neglect, that is, there is no Power to hang a Man, if he does not take notice of the Law; and there is power to hang him if he does. This makes ≈øome difference as to puni≈øhment, but none as to duty, for the obligation ari≈øes from the direction of the Law, and not from the external force to compel the ob≈øervance, and the direction of the Law binds when there are, and when there are not Courts of Judicature to put it in execution.

2. There is no Tribunal for the Correction of Princes but Gods: Very true! And therefore they are not accountable to the People for mal-admini≈øtration; Their Per≈øons are ≈øacred, their Authority irre≈øi≈øtable and unalienable. And the≈øe were the Inferences, that hitherto the Men of the Church of England have drawn from this Doctrine; but the Dr. hath found out a new Inference, that the Subjects may re≈øi≈øt him, and ≈øhake off his Authority, and kill him too if need be; and all for this weighty Rea≈øon, becau≈øe they have put another in the po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his Throne: I know the Dr. calls it Providence, but that is the Engli≈øh of it.

3. 'Tis true God hath re≈øerved to him≈øelf the Correction of Sovereign Princes, and ≈øomtimes he doth here actually correct and puni≈øh them, and di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion is ≈øometimes de≈øign'd as a Puni≈øhment by God him≈øelf. But ≈øtill the Que≈øtion returns, is ≈øuch a di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by providence a ≈øufficient evidence, that God hath given away the Kingdom from the di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed to the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øor of the Throne; and 'till that can be made out all the≈øe Arguments and Inferences ≈øignifie nothing. And that is manife≈øtly fal≈øe in the Ca≈øe of David, he for the puni≈øhment of his ≈øins was di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed by his own Son; but God by that providence did not take away the Kingdom from David and give it to Ab≈øolom: And God had then erected no Univer≈øal Tribunal for the deci≈øion of ≈øuch Ca≈øes, no more than he has now. The Que≈øtion therefore, is not whether there are ≈øome Ca≈øes too big for a Legal Deci≈øion or Humane Courts, or whether God hath re≈øerv'd to his own judgment the correction of Princes, and transferring Kingdoms: But the Que≈øtion is, whether the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne by providence dive≈øts the Rightful King of the Crown, and of the Allegiance of the Subjects, while his Per≈øon is in being, and his Legal Right remains. And that the matters being re≈øerved to God's own Tribunal does not prove; the nature of the thing indeed proves that ca≈øes that cannot be redre≈ø≈øed by publick Government, are re≈øerved to God's own judgment; but their being ≈øo re≈øerved (which is the full of the Drs. Argument) does not prove, that therefore every Providential Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, is God's final determination or any warrantable evidence to conclude from thence, that God hath made him a King, and the People his Subjects. Dr. Sherlock makes another Collection from providence in this very ca≈øe. No ∆≤ ≈øurpations can extingui≈øh the Right and Title of the natural Prince; ≈øuch ∆≤≈øurpers, Ca≈øe of Re≈øi≈øt. p. 132. the they have the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the ≈øupreme Power, yet they have no right to it; and tho God for wi≈øe rea≈øons may ≈øometimes permit ≈øuch ∆≤≈øurpations; yet while his Providence ≈øecures the Per≈øons of ≈øuch depo≈øed and bani≈øhed Princes from violence, he ≈øecures their Title too.

4. The Dr. ≈øays, that in correction of Princes and transferring Kingdoms, God does not confine him≈øelf to determine on the ≈øide of humane Right, but acts with a Sovereign Authority, and gives the Kingdoms of the World to whom he plea≈øes. And what then? and therefore the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne by providence is God's giving the Kingdom, but that does not follow: And God's acting with a Sovereign
Authority (which the Dr. intimates as a Rea≈øon) does not prove it, for in all acts of Providence, God acts with a Sovereign Authority if by Sovereign Authority the Dr. means acting independantly, and without re≈øpect to the Laws and Rules God hath pre≈øcribed to others. This is the ≈øame in ca≈øes under the cognizance of Laws and Humane Courts, as well as in tho≈øe which are above them, and ≈øuch acting by a Sovereign Authority is no Rule for mankind, nor warrant for practice. But if by Gods acting with a Sovereign Authority the Dr. means, That God as Lord and Proprietor of the World may di≈øpo≈øe of it as he ≈øees good, and actually does ≈øo in ≈øuch a way as may warrant practice, and confer a good Right and Title, as when he ordered the I≈øraelites to ≈øpoil the Aegyptians. This was an Act of Sovereign Authority, but cannot be called Providence, but comes under the notion of a Law, and they were warranted to take the Aegyptians goods not from providence giving them opportunity, but from God's expre≈øs will impowering and authorizing them ≈øo to do. In like manner God may if he plea≈øe di≈øpo≈øe of Kingdoms, and private e≈øtates by his Sovereign Authority; but if he does ≈øo, he extingui≈øhes the Legal Right of the former owner, and conveys it to whom he gives it. And it can never be concluded that he does ≈øo from providence only, the ends and de≈øigns of which are my≈øterious and to us unknown, but from ≈øome further evidence and notice of the Divine Will: But the Dr. confounds God's providence with his Laws, and makes one a Rule of practice as well as the other. God governs the World by his providence, as well as by his Laws, but he hath not made his providence, nor directed us to ob≈øerve it as a Rule of life. And therefore the Drs. proof is prepo≈øterous, for although there are ca≈øes re≈øerv'd to Gods own judgment; altho God may act by a Sovereign Authority, that is nothing to his purpo≈øe, except he proves likewi≈øe, that the events of providence are God's final ≈øentence; and that he would have the World take notice of them as ≈øuch. But in≈øtead of that the Dr. is for beginning at the other end, and proves that God's providence is his final determination, and a Rule to be ob≈øerved, becau≈øe there are Ca≈øes re≈øerved to his own judgment: And therefore this proves indeed, that there is a difference in the two Ca≈øes, but does not prove, that there is any difference in providence, which is the only thing that needs to be proved; the one is under publick Government, the other is immediatly under the Government of God, but they are both immediatly under Providence: And a direct an≈øwer mu≈øt affect that, and ≈øhew how providence is le≈øs Gods Act, or a le≈øs Act of his Sovereign Authority, with re≈øpect to private Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions than to Thrones; how the ≈øame Providence, which in one Ca≈øe is Paramount to Laws, di≈ø≈øolves their obligation, cancels the bond of Oaths, and di≈øpo≈øes Crowns, in the other does nothing at all, but is under the Authority of a Ju≈øtice of Peace or a Con≈øtable. But this (which is the main point) the Dr. does not attempt to an≈øwer, but in≈øtead of that tells us, that in one ca≈øe, God hath erected humane Judicatures, but the other are re≈øerved to his own judgment, i. e. there is ≈øome difference as to the things but none as to Providence, which is the only que≈øtion: For a humane Judicature does not alter the nature of Providence; and if providence be God's Decree, Order, and Council, then it is ≈øo notwith≈øtanding any humane Judicature; and it is ≈øomewhat ≈øtrange, that a humane Judicature ≈øhould determine again≈øt God's Orders, and Decrees any more than humane Laws. And here I de≈øire to be re≈øolved in 2 Que≈øtions.
1. How it comes to pa≈øs, that a humane Judicatory is a greater confinement to Providence than a humane Law.

2. Whether God hath erected humane Judicatories to determine the Rights of private men, any otherwi≈øe, or for any other purpo≈øes than he hath humane Entails to determine the Rights of Kings; and if not, then I ≈øuppo≈øe it will follow, that as humane Judicatories are a Rea≈øon why Providence (as the Dr. ≈øays) has no effect at all on ≈øuch Per≈øonal Rights, ≈øo humane Entails al≈øo will be a Rea≈øon why providence has no effect at all on ≈øuch Regal Rights, or at lea≈øt the one will be as good a Rea≈øon as the other.

At la≈øt the Dr. comes to prove his point from the Poet, and tells me, The Poet would have taught him the difference between the≈øe two Ca≈øes: And I confe≈øs, I ≈øhould rather have expected this Doctrin in a Poet than in a Divine.

q.l: Reges in ip≈øos Imperium e≈øt Jovis.

div.p: Now the Poet is not for him neither, for all that he ≈øays (as the Dr. quotes him) is, that the Government of Kings is over their own Subjects, and the Government of Jupiter is over Kings them≈øelves. And that he might very well think without the Drs. notion of Providence; and what opinion the Poet had of Providence does not appear. But however, tho this is not for the Drs. Purpo≈øe, it mu≈øt be own'd, that the Method is very proper; for proofs from a Poet do very well ≈øuit with Poetical Divinity.

The Dr. goes on; Be≈øides according to my Principles,P. 47. Kings mu≈øt be throughly ≈øetled in their Governments, before it becomes unlawful for Subjects to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them; and then if he will make the Ca≈øes parallel, be who unju≈øtly ≈øeizes another mans e≈øtate, mu≈øt be throughly ≈øetled in it, before it becomes unlawful to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs him, but that no private man can be, who is under the Government of Laws, who has not the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of his E≈øtate given him by Law; and when he has, whether right or wrong, he mu≈øt not be violently di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed again. Now I crave the Drs. good leave, to return him one of his own Complements, is he in
‚Ä¢ e≈øt, or in earne≈øt? and certainly ≈øuch things as the≈øe were never ≈øaid in earne≈øt by a man of the Drs. Character. The di≈øpute is between the Providential Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, and of a private E≈øtate, now to make the Ca≈øes parallel, in the private Ca≈øe there mu≈øt be a Legal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; that is there is a Parallel between Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, but between Providential and Legal, which is the only thing in controver≈øie, there is none. We are not now di≈øputing about the notion of a thorough Settlement; and for once let us take it in the Drs. ≈øen≈øe, and ≈øee what a fine Parallel he makes, a thorough Settlement of an U≈øurper on the Throne, is an actual and vi≈øible Settlement, not a Legal one; the Settlement of a private Per≈øon in an e≈øtate, is a Legal Settlement; and to make the Ca≈øes Parallel, one mu≈øt be actually ≈øetled, not legally, and the other mu≈øt be legally ≈øetled: And ≈øo a thorough Settlement in one ≈øen≈øe, is Parallel to a thorough Settlement in another ≈øen≈øe; even ju≈øt as a Tryal of skill, is Parallel to a Tryal at Law, or the Drs. Picture is Parallel to him≈øelf. But Parallel is a term in Mathematicks, as Settlement is a term in Law. But when they come to be apply'd to U≈øurpation, they mu≈øt change their ≈øignification, and mean the clean contrary. And there is all the rea≈øon in the World, for if U≈øurper ≈øignifies a King, why may not Settlement ≈øignifie Illegal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, and Parallel ≈øignifie inequality? Now 'tis no marvel the Dr. tells his An≈øwerer, he expects to hear no more from him; for who is able to an≈øwer ≈øuch terrible arguments as the≈øe?

The Dr. here tells us, that by his Principles Kings mu≈øt be throughly ≈øetled in their Governments before it becomes unlawful for Subjects to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs them: Now I cannot tell what his Principles are, but this I can tell, that his Arguments prove no ≈øuch thing. I know indeed, that to get the Convocation of his ≈øide, he hath given us a new ≈øen≈øe of a thorough Settlement, and that (as the chief) is the Con≈øent and ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion of the States and the great Body of the Nation. And when he hath done that, he takes his leave on't, for his Arguments neither concern a thorough Settlement in his ≈øen≈øe, nor in the true ≈øen≈øe: For what has God's removing and ≈øetting up Kings, Ca≈øe of Alleg. p. 12. 14. the events of Providence being his Decree and Order; That tho≈øe are all rightful Kings who are placed in the Throne by God, that he is our King who is ≈øetled in the Throne in the Actual Admini≈øtration of Sovereign Power, &c. That the Scripture account means only the Powers that be, i. e. tho≈øe that are in the Actual Admini≈øtration of Government, &c.p. 21. And what is all this to the Peoples con≈øent? And here I ask the Dr. this plain Que≈øtion, does the Peoples con≈øent convey any thing to the Government, or does it not? if not how comes it nece≈ø≈øary? or how comes it to be only unlawful to di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs Princes when they are throughly ≈øetled, i. e. when the People have con≈øented, but not before: But if it does convey any thing, then Providence alone does not do it; and then it does not follow, that when a Prince is in the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of the Throne, and in the
Actual Admini≈øtration of Government, that he hath God's Authority; for that is a ≈øtrange Authority from God which the People may chu≈øe, or refu≈øe at their plea≈øure. But the truth is the Drs. notion of a thorough Settlement, hath rooted up the very foundations of Government, and plainly center in the Commonwealth Principles. And that is the bottom of the bu≈øine≈øs, and for the proof of this I will be tryed by the Dr. him≈øelf. In his Ca≈øe of Allegiance di≈øputing again≈øt a Legal Right,p. 25. he thus delivers him≈øelf: To ≈øay that God ≈øets up no Prince, who a≈øcends the Throne without a humane and legal Right, is to ≈øay that the Right of Government is not derived from God without the con≈øent of the People; for if God can't make a King without their con≈øent declared by their Laws, (and if the Dr. will give me leave, I ≈øay without their con≈øent declared by them≈øelves, or the States, or the great body of the Nation) the Authority mu≈øt be derived from the People, not from God, or at lea≈øt if it be God's Authority; yet God cannot give it him≈øelf without the People, nor otherwi≈øe than as they have directed him by their Laws: I add by their con≈øent; But what becomes of the Drs. thorough Settlement by the Con≈øent of the People all this while, why it may be, he had forgot it: But however he tells us, that it is his Principle, and that may be too; but heretofore men u≈øed to bring Arguments to prove, and not to confute their Principles.

The Dr. goes on, as our Author has ≈øtated the ca≈øe, it ≈øignifies nothing to the pre≈øent purpo≈øe, for whether private mens e≈øtates be ≈øetled by a Divine or Humane Entail, it is the ≈øame ca≈øe if they ≈øuffer injury from their Fellow Subjects, they mu≈øt ≈øeek for redre≈øs from Publick Government. That is, the ≈øaying, that the Land of Judah was entailed by a Divine Entail, as well as the Crown, is not to the pre≈øent purpo≈øe, tho the great ≈øtre≈øs of the Drs. An≈øwer lies in the difference between a Divine and a Humane Entail And it is plain enough from thence, that a Divine Entail made no difference as to Providence and Property between that and other Nations: But his rea≈øon is that private injuries may be redre≈ø≈øed by publick Government; well! and that is a rea≈øon to prove that no providential di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a private man, is any warrant again≈øt Law. But it is no rea≈øon to prove, that a providential di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of a Prince is ≈øuch a warrant, but the contrary, for being above or under the Law makes no alteration in the nature of Providence; and it is odd to ≈øay, that Providence has power and efficacy in Ca≈øes where the Law has none, but has none where it has. But this hath been con≈øidered before; and as to the matter of God's ≈øetling the Land of Canaan by Divine Entail: The Dr. after having ≈øaid, that he could have told me, how to have applied the Ca≈øe to the purpo≈øe, (and methinks he that hath ≈øaid ≈øo little to the purpo≈øe, need not have neglected what had been to his purpo≈øe) ≈øhews ≈øome difference between the Land of Canaan and other Countries: But tho≈øe are not at all to his purpo≈øe.

In Canaan (≈øaith he) where God allotted every tribe and family their inheritance, none could pretend to a Right to any portion of Land, but what was allotted him. But in other Countries which were left in Common, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Occupation gave a Right: Very true, but not when they were not left in common, but property was inclo≈øed by Laws, Legal Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion then only gave a Right. But ≈øaith he, Thus in Judah none had an ordinary Right to the Crown, but tho≈øe that were nominated by God, or had the Crown de≈øcended on them by a Divine Entail. But in other Countries Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Occupation gave a Right to the Allegiance of Subjects. Now if the Dr. would have made this Parallel he ≈øhould have ≈øaid, in other Countries, where Government was left in Common; and then it had been true enough, for no body had a better Right; but it is not ≈øo, where the Crown is entail'd by Laws, Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion gives no more Right to the Crown, than it gives to private E≈øtates.

In Canaan (≈øaith he) when God had ≈øetled ≈øuch an inheritance in a family, it could never be perpetually alienated, and tho it were ≈øold, it could be ≈øold for no longer time than till the year of Jubilee, when all e≈øtates were to return to their old Proprietors again. Right; and this was the Law of Canaan, and by virtue of that they did ≈øo return, but had there been no ≈øuch Law, would the Land-once ≈øold, have
then by virtue merely of a Divine Entail, return'd to their old Proprietors? But in other Countries men may part with their E≈øtates for ever: Right again, becau≈øe the Laws permit them ≈øo to do: But if the Laws of other Countries, had provided that all E≈øtates ≈øhould return to their old Proprietors at ≈øuch a year, they would have done ≈øo too, tho the Provi≈øion had been made only by a Humane Law. Thus (≈øaith he) in the Kingdom of Judah, tho God by his Sovereign Authority might ≈øet up a Providential King, yet this did not cut off the Entail; but whenever the true Heir, appeared, Subjects if they were at Liberty, were bound to make him King, and di≈øpo≈ø≈øe≈øs the ∆≤≈øurper; but in other Kingdoms, a Kingdom may be lo≈øt, as well as an inheritance ≈øold for ever. Thus that is ju≈øt as an E≈øtate in Judah and other Countries, might or might not be ≈øold, but according to the Laws of each Country; in like manner, as in the Kingdom of Judah the Inheritance of the Crown was not alienable, tho the E≈øtates for a time were, even ≈øo, in other Kingdoms a Kingdom may be lo≈øt, as well as an inheritance ≈øold for ever. And that is to ≈øay again, that as in other Kingdoms an inheritance may be ≈øold by the con≈øent of the parties intere≈ø≈øed, even ≈øo a Government may be lo≈øt, without, and contrary to the con≈øent of the Proprietor, and right owner. For ≈øuch Parallels as the≈øe, otherwi≈øe or quite contrary might have ≈øerved, as well as Thus; The Dr. tells me what I ≈øay in this Ca≈øe is pretty, becau≈øe that between the Divine Entail, and Gods expre≈øs command concerning Canaan, and the Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion by providence and a Humane Entail there is ≈øome likene≈øs. I am ≈øorry I cannot return all his Complement, this is very pretty indeed, but there is no likene≈øs at all.

We are come to the Drs. An≈øwer to the objection,P. 48. that the Laws of the Land are the mea≈øure of duty, and Rule of Con≈øcience, &c. and the ≈øum of the An≈øwer is, they are ≈øo, when they do not contradict the Laws of God, but when they do they are no Rule, but their obligation mu≈øt give place to Divine Authority, and ≈øuppo≈øe the Law ≈øhould forbid owning any King, but the Right Heir; and the Law of God ≈øhould command obedience to him, that actually po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øes the Throne we mu≈øt obey the Law of God. To this I an≈øwered, where is this Law of God,Po≈øt≈øcript. p. 11. that commands us to obey U≈øurpers? where is it affirm'd in expre≈øs terms, or deduced from thence by evident con≈øequence? He replies, he hath ≈øhewed it before, and it is in his book ≈øtill and there I may ≈øee it. As if I had not at all con≈øider'd, what he had ≈øaid in his Book in my An≈øwer.
